answers: supersessionism [or supersessionist theology; accept replacement theology; do not accept "covenant theology" due to mention in question]
People of the Book [or People of the Scriptures; or ahl al-kitab; accept dhimmis]
parts: Name this belief among some Christians that the covenant of God with the Jews is no longer valid and that all Jews must become Christians.

Though Pius XII fully endorsed supersessionism in the 1943 encyclical Mystici corporis Christi (mis-teek-ee kor-por-ihs kris-tee), the Catholic Church moved away from the position during this liberalizing 1962-1965 council called by John XXIII (the twenty-third).

According to Islamic doctrine, though Christians, Jews, and Sabeans committed tahrif by corrupting divine revelation, they have a special status denoted by this term in reference to their adherence to certain texts.

answers: Great Molasses Flood [or Boston Molasses Flood; prompt on Molasses Flood with "where?"; prompt on flood]
sleeping [or napping; or taking a nap; or dreaming; or snoring]
parts: Name this "Silent" President whose first words after being inaugurated President in 1923 after Warren G. Harding's death was "Better get that fixed" in response to broken steps at his house.
Coolidge served as governor of Massachusetts during this 1919 event. This event occurred when a hot North End day caused a storage tank at Purity Distilling Company to burst, killing 21 people.

H.L. Mencken mocked Calvin Coolidge's hands-off nature by writing "Nero fiddled while Rome burned, but Coolidge" only performs this activity. William Howard Taft constructed a rooftop porch on the White House for this activity.

answers: the Metamorphoses [or Metamorphoseon libri; do not accept or prompt on "(The) Metamorphosis"]
Ali Smith [prompt on Smith; do not accept or prompt on "Ali"] (the second novel is Autumn)
parts: Name this book by Ovid which recounts the stories of many mythological transformations.

In reference to a story from Ovid's Metamorphoses, the intersex Cal markets himself as the god Hermaphroditus while working at a nightclub in this author's novel Middlesex. This author also wrote The Virgin Suicides.

Ovid's myth of Iphis, who is transformed into a man, is reinterpreted in the story of the sisters Anthea and Imogen in this author's novel Girl Meets Boy. In a novel by this author, Elisabeth Demand recalls her friendship with her neighbor, the 101-year-old songwriter Daniel Gluck.

answers: sampling [or sampling a signal; or undersampling; accept discretization of a signal or answers indicating conversion from continuous to discrete; accept answers indicating conversion from analog to digital but not the other way around; prompt on reconstructing a signal or similar by asking "the results of what process are used to reconstruct a signal?"; prompt on convolutions by asking "the results of what process are being convoluted?"]
parts: Name this process, which can also be done by multiplying with the Shah function. The usual lower bound on the number of times this process must be done is a consequence of the properties of sinc (sink) interpolation.
The Shah function consists of this function repeated periodically. A system outputs its impulse response when this function, representing a unit impulse, is input.
The sinc function is defined as sin x over x everywhere except at this x-value, where it is set to 1. The Dirac delta function can be thought of as having an infinitely tall spike at this x-value.

answers: Seven Against Thebes (The king is Adrastus)
parts: After an Argive king saw the figures of a lion and a boar on the shields of two members of this group, he marries his daughters to those members. After this group dies, that king flees on his horse Arion (ar-ee-awn).

This god helps King Admetus (ad-mee-toos) to yoke a boar and a lion to a chariot so that he can marry Alcestis (al-kess-tiss). This god served under Admetus as punishment for killing Deiphyle (day-puh-leh), and later gets the Fates drunk to get a favor on his behalf.
This hero has to kill the Erymanthian (ehr-y-man-thee-an) Boar and the Nemean (neh-mee-an) Lion as 2 of the 12 labors he is forced to undergo by Eurystheus (yur-is-thee-us).
Name this American choreographer of The Concert as well as On the Town and Fiddler on the Roof.
Several of the ballets that Robbins choreographed, including On the Town and Fancy Free, were collaborations with this American composer of the Kaddish Symphony.

Another Bernstein and Robbins collaboration was this adaptation of Romeo and Juliet set in a Puerto Rican neighborhood of the Upper West Side. This musical juxtaposes the romance between Tony and Maria with the gang rivalry of the Jets and Sharks.
Name this type of place where the ghost of a woman condemned to the death penalty appears to a man who talks with the drag queen Belize about what Heaven looks like.
Belize describes Heaven as a city overgrown with flowering weeds in this Tony Kushner play where Roy Cohn is hospitalized for AIDS that he pretends is cancer.
In this play, the hospital patient Dr. Vivian Bearing frequently muses on John Donne's "Death, be not proud" before she dies of ovarian cancer and walks toward the light.

answers: unimolecular reactions [anti-prompt on decomposition, isomerization, dissociation]
transition-state theory [or TST; or activated complex theory]
parts: Name these reactions governed the RRKM model, which assumes that key vibrational modes must become active before they can occur.

Marcus improved on the work of Rice, Ramsperger, and Kassel by incorporating this framework. When considering unimolecular reactions using this framework, the activated molecule is found at the top of a PES (P-E-S) and denoted with a double dagger.

Transition state theory allowed for the development of the Eyring equation, a theoretically-justified modification of this empirical equation for the rate constant written using a pre-exponential factor.

answers: Grand Duke of Vladimir [or Grand Prince of Vladimir; or Velikiy Kniaz Vladimir; prompt on Grand Prince; prompt on Prince of Vladimir]
Alexander Nevsky [Alexander Yaroslavich Nevsky; or Saint Alexander I; prompt on Alexander; prompt on Alexander I]
parts: Name this royal office from which Vsevolod the Big Nest and Yaroslav II created the leading power in Russia at the turn of the 13th century following Andrei's move of a throne away from Suzdal.
This man was Grand Duke of Vladimir from 1220 to 1263. In 1242 he led the Russian coalition that defeated the Teutonic Knights in the "Massacre on Ice" at Lake Peipus.

Nevsky also had three non-consecutive reigns as grand prince of a city of this name on the north tip of Lake Ilmen, where Ivan the Terrible ordered a massacre in 1570. A different city of this name prefaces it with the word "Nizhny," or "lower."

answers: Ferde Grofé [or Ferdie Grofé; or Ferdy Grofé; or Ferdinand Rudolph von Grofé]
film scores [accept movie scores or obvious equivalents; do NOT accept or prompt on "films" alone]
parts: Name this location that titles a five-movement orchestral suite with movements including "On the Trail" and "Cloudburst." The first public performance of that piece depicting this location was conducted by Paul Whiteman.
The Grand Canyon Suite was written by this American composer, who took inspiration from Huckleberry Finn for his 1926 Mississippi Suite. He also orchestrated Rhapsody in Blue.
Grofé also composed a number of works of this type like Early to Bed and Diamond Jim. Ennio Morricone and Bernard Herrmann were known for works of this type, including one for Psycho.

answers: Goryeo dynasty [accept Koryo; do not accept or prompt on Goguryeo or Korea alone]
Tripitaka [accept Tipitaka or Pali Canon or Daejanggyeong or Samsang; accept  sanzang; accept Three Baskets]
Genghis Khan [accept Temüjin or Chingis Khan; prompt on Khan alone]
parts: Name this dynasty whose founder constructed ten Buddhist monasteries and popularized the Jogye Order which had been founded during an earlier dynasty.
Choe Yun-ui's printing helped the Goryeo complete a copy of this work on over 80,000 woodblocks. In 730, Zhìshēng (jhi-shung) provided the basic structure for this largest canon of Buddhist beliefs.

This leader's son Ögedei destroyed the original copies of the Tripitaka during the first of seven Mongol invasions of the Goryeo. This Mongol's "secret" yassa law code allowed for free practice of Buddhism.

answers: post-mortem interval [or PMI; accept descriptive answers about the time of death or elapsed time since death]
human corpses [or cadavers; or dead bodies; accept body farms]
rigor mortis [prompt on descriptive answers, such as muscle stiffening]
parts: Name or describe this quantity that the Glaister equation calculates by assuming certain objects lose 1.5 Fahrenheit degrees per hour. In a common application of entomology (en-tuh-MOL-uh-jee), this quantity can be estimated by observing the life cycle stage of blowflies.

The Glaister equation models temperature loss in these objects, which are studied at a "farm" established by William Bass at the University of Tennessee. These objects are studied by a coroner to determine cause of death.
PMI cannot be determined accurately using the onset of this phenomenon, which occurs because ATP depletion prevents the separation of actin-myosin cross bridges.

answers: religions [accept faiths and other obvious equivalents]
Iroquois [or Haudenosaunee; accept Seneca specifically; prompt on Native Americans or American Indians]
parts: Name these systems which Wallace categorized into monotheistic, Olympian, communal, and shamanic types. Examples of these belief systems include Baha'i and Sikhism.

Wallace wrote the paper "Revitalization Movements" after fieldwork studying this people group and their religion. These people name the "bifurcate merging" kinship system in a typology by Lewis Henry Morgan, who wrote an ethnography of them.
This anthropologist's work on religion includes the unfinished doctoral thesis On Prayer. He studied the hau ("how") system of the Maori in a book on a "total social fact" regarding reciprocity.

answers: Don Quixote [or The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha or El ingenioso hidalgo Don Quixote de la Mancha]
lawyer [or licenciado; accept The Lawyer of Glass or El licenciado Vidriera]
parts: Name this city. While imprisoned here, Cervantes wrote plays titled El Trato de this city and Los baños de this city and befriended fellow captive Antonio de Sosa, who penned a "Topography" of it.
Garcés argued that Cervantes' time in Algiers led to the groundbreaking inclusion of non-European characters in this novel, like Sancho Panza's morisco friend Ricote.

Garcés argued that Don Quixote was a type of madman called a "figurative incarceration" that Cervantes wrote about after being imprisoned in Algiers. Another such character is a man with this profession, Tomás Rodaja, who appears in a Cervantes story titled for this job "of Glass."

answers: Nevado Ojos del Salado [accept Salty Eyes or Eyes of the Salty One]
Chile and Argentina [both answers required; accept answers in either order; accept answers using the Republic of Chile or the Argentine Republic]
parts: Name this tallest active volcano in the world. Its eastern side is home to a crater lake which is probably the highest-altitude lake in the world.

Ojos del Salado straddles the border between these two countries. In 1972, an Uruguayan rugby team resorted to cannibalism when they crashed on the border of these two countries, whose most frequent crossing is near Mendoza.
The Chilean-Argentinian border naturally runs along this South American mountain range whose peaks include Mount Aconcagua.

answers: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac [or Federal National Mortgage Association and Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation; do not prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name these two government-sponsored enterprises which are now prohibited from owning Alt-A loans as a result of findings at that hearing.

Part of the reason for Fannie's and Freddie's failure was their purchase of these high-risk loans to homeowners with lower credit scores. In 2012, Wells Fargo was fined $175 million for forcing Hispanics and African-Americans to take these loans.
Fannie and Freddie were finally acquired by the government in September of this year. The ongoing crisis helped Barack Obama defeat John McCain in this year's presidential election.
Name this poem by Felicia Hemans about a boy who bravely dies with a burning ship.
That later update to "Casabianca" is by this poet. "Victory filled up / the little rented boat" until "everything was rainbow, rainbow, rainbow!" in this poet's poem "The Fish."

The title "Gentleman of Shalott" quotes "Half is enough" in a Bishop poem, referencing the line "I am half sick of shadows" from this poet's "The Lady of Shalott." This poet wrote about a cavalry "Plunged in the battery-smoke" in "The Charge of the Light Brigade."
Name this type of place depicted in that untitled Kerry James Marshall painting. Another artist depicted one of these places in 5 different paintings, one of which is subtitled Foot Medication.

Another of Roy Lichtenstein's depictions of his studio prominently features this older artwork, which depicts a scene similar to a detail found in The Joy of Life. Five figures link arms in this painting.
Lichtenstein's paintings of his studio drew inspiration from this artist's paintings The Red Studio, The Pink Studio, and La Danse.

answers: stellar pulsations [or stellar oscillations; accept pulsating variable stars; prompt on variability or variation in luminosity; prompt on expansions or contractions or changing size or similar descriptive answers]
parts: Name these phenomena that stars can undergo in either radial or non-radial modes. RR Lyrae (LIE-ray) and Delta Cepheid (SEE-fee-id) stars are intrinsic variable stars whose changes in luminosity are driven by these phenomena.

In non-variable stars, oscillations are divided into two primary modes, gravity wave-driven g-modes, and these acoustically-driven modes. The frequency of oscillations in this mode is the Lamb frequency.
Solar-like oscillations in stars are driven primarily by a turbulent form of this process in the star's outer layers. In this mode of heat transfer, hot plasma rises and colder plasma descends.
Name this book of 153 aphorisms, which opens by quoting "life does not live" and was inspired by its author's exile to America.
This Frankfurt School philosopher penned Minima Moralia for the 50th birthday of Max Horkheimer with whom he had written a book describing the "culture industry."

That book by Adorno and Horkheimer is titled for The Dialectic of this process, which names an 18th-century period of cultural development and freedom that Kant defined as "man's emergence from his self-imposed immaturity."
The chikungunya virus is spread by two species in this genus of mosquitos; aegypti, and the invasive albopictus, which spread by hitchhiking on used car tires.

The symptoms of chikungunya (chick-uhn-goon-yuh) can be confused with those of this other mosquito-spread disease, which had a 2015-16 outbreak. Some governments advised women to avoid pregnancy during the outbreak due to the possiblility of a birth defect called microencephaly.

An attempt at vaccination against chikungunya (chick-uhn-goon-yuh) was a vaccine of this type, where the virus is kept alive but made less pathogenic. This type of vaccine also describes the MMR vaccine.
